title: when to take pcr test
story: Situations when you still MUST take PCR test as major change limits number of testsA major change to UK Covid testing rules has come into force. Here’s everything you need to know about the rule change and when you will still be expected to do a PCR testA major rule change means fewer people need to take a PCR test to confirmthey are Covid positive Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Jan | comments A new Covid testing rule has come into effect in England as of today, January , under which fewer people will be required to get a PCR to test for infection. Under this rule, someone who tests positive on a lateral flow test will no longer need to get a follow-up PCRthey have no symptoms of the virus. If you have a positive lateral flow test, you will need to self-isolate immediately. Since you no longer need to double check with a PCR, this means your -day self-isolation period starts earlier. If you get a negative lateral flow on day six and seven, then you can even end your self-isolation early.Despite the new rule, there are still over a dozen reasons when you still have to get a PCR test.  The government has outlined certain exceptions to the rule change. For instance, you should always get a PCR testyou have symptoms of Covid, regardless of the result of lateral flow.This includes not just the three classic signs of high temperature, new or persistent cough and loss of smell or taste, but the more unusual symptoms that are being increasingly reported.You should also get a PCR doneyouaposve been in contact with someone who’s tested positive, evenyou are fully vaccinated.  There are many other reasons to get a PCR test in England under government guidance. Hereaposs the full list:Youaposve been asked to get a test by a local council or someone from NHS Test and Trace A GP or other health professional has asked you to get a test Youaposre taking part in a government pilot project Youaposve been asked to get a test to confirm a positive result Youaposve received an unclear result and were told to get a second test Youaposre in the National Tactical Response Group You are due to have an operation in hospital People who are eligible for the £ Test and Trace Support Paymentwill be asked to take a PCR so they can access financial support People participating in research or surveillance programmes may still be asked to take a follow-up PCR test The one million people in England who are at particular risk of becoming seriously ill from Covid and are involved in new research of treatmentsThe rules and exceptions y between nations. For instance, in Scotland you should book a PCR testyou have had two or more void lateral flow test results. Similarly, in Wales, anyone who is in the clinically vulnerable group will still need to take a PCR testtheir lateral flow is positive but they have no symptoms. title: woman 22 mortified realising belly
story: Woman, , mortied realising belly button was incorrectly pierced  years agoFaith Kelly, , went viral on TikTok after revealing how long it had taken her to notice something wrong with her navel piercing.Faith Kelly was horried when she realised her belly button was incorrectly pierced Image: @faithlouisak TikTokByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA woman was left mortied when she realised she had her belly button incorrectly pierced eight years after getting it done. Faith Kelly, , went viral on TikTok after revealing how long it had taken her to notice something wrong with her navel piercing. In the video, that has been liked more than , times, Faith explained how she recently swapped the Swarovksi stud that she had in for a hoop. She says immediately after replacing the jewellery she felt something wasnapost right. Faith, from Essex, said that is when she realised her navel wasnapost pierced at all - but her actual stomach. She said: Iaposve just realised, when I say I have a belly piercing, I have a BELLY piercing. So thataposs my belly. Thataposs my belly button. I donapost have my belly button pierced. I have my belly pierced. What the f***  She also urged other viewers to not make the same mistake and captioned the video: Check your piercings right now. One viewer replied: You have to have enough skin to pierce through so they should’ve checked that first with their fingers. Instead they’ve pierced your actual belly! Another added: SORRY WHAT ! A third joked: New fear unlocked. Shockingly, this isnapost the first time something like that has happened.Last year, a woman, who goes by the name Tyykidd on TikTok, took to the app to share the results of having her belly button pierced in New Jersey. Never get your belly button pierced at the shore. Worst mistake ever, she wrote alongside the clip. They missed the whole belly button. I want a refund for my time, money  FEELINGS. In the clip, the woman showed off her belly piercing, which does appear very high - however many commenters pointed out she has a very small belly button, which could mean the piercing would not have fit in the ordinary place. title: woman who shed 4st six
story: Woman who shed st in six months says weight-loss saved le her after finding lumpAndrea Richardson, , from Coppull in Wigan, Lancashire, was delighted to have shed the pounds through Slimming World - but was left stunned after she found a lump only revealed after the weight lossAndrea Richardson lost four stone after joining Slimming World Image: Lancashire Post   SWNSByDouglas Whitbread:,  Jan | commentsA woman who lost a staggering four stone in six months is claiming shedding the weight saved her le by allowing her to discover a cancerous tumour in her breast.Andrea Richardson, a -year-old Slimming World member, was delighted to have dropped the pounds through Slimming World but was shocked when she found a lump revealed by the weight loss.The mum-of-two went for tests after finding the lump and was diagnosed with breast cancer. She has since had the tumour removed and been given the all-clear. Now, she is crediting the weight loss with saving her le - saying otherwise, she would never have found the lump. The tumour was really close to my chest wall, so close in fact that it didnapost even get picked up on the mammogram,” she said. If I hadnapost lost all that weight, I would never have found the tumour as early as I did, and my story could have been very dferent to the one I am sharing today. Caught early, breast cancer treatment has a much higher success rate, so Slimming World has well and truly saved my le. Andrea, who works as a social investment Team Leader at housing group Onward Homes, made the decision to get into better shape in July . She said she had been overweight since having her first daughter in  and decided it was time for a change. She joined her local branch of Slimming World in her village of Coppull, near Wigan, Lancs., and said she was thrilled when she shed an impressive  stone lb. But in August , after she heard about a friendaposs cancer scare, Andrea decided to check herself and couldnapost believe it when she found a lump in her left breast. Within days she had received the shocking news that she had cancer. She added: It has changed me in many ways. I have more confidence and give priority to myself now whereas I probably didnapost before. I feel very lucky as it could have been a very dferent story. Women put it off, getting checked. Donapost. As it could have been a very dferent outcome had it not been caught as early.  I have always been overweight since having my first daughter, Elizabeth, in . When I had my second daughter, Isabelle, who is now , my weight fluctuated up and down - le makes you fluctuate. In July  I decided it was time for a change. The bigger clothes were getting tighter, and it was time to do something about it. Everything happened so quickly, I was referred to Lancashire Breast Clinic and before I knew it, I had been diagnosed with stage  breast cancer. Andrea underwent two operations, as the first one was unable to remove all of the tumours, followed by intensive radiotherapy treatment which ended five months later. She finally got to ring the bell at the Rosemere Cancer Centre in Preston on Christmas Eve  with her eldest daughter Elizabeth, , by her side. Andrea now runs the Slimming World group as she hopes to inspire others. And now, she has also taken over the running of Slimming World in Coppull as she wants to inspire members and make a dference. news uk-news worlds-most-prolic-surrogate-mum-"Surrogate mum accidentally gave away own babyBySarah Arnold:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Carole Horlock is the world’s most prolic surrogate after having  babies for other people. But there is one child she is desperate to see again, the boy who turned out to be her own son by her husband Paul.Carole gave birth to the lb oz baby in June , believing he was another couple’s child, created from her egg but with the sperm of the other husband. But the couple carried out a DNA test six weeks after the birth and discovered the baby was by Carole’s husband Paul. Carole and Paul agreed they could still adopt him, a decision Carole does not regret, but she was devastated when contact with the couple broke down, and now thinks of her son “all the time”.  She is now on the Adoption Contact Register hoping he would like to meet her when he turns  this year. Carole, whose achievement has been entered in the Guinness World Records, says: “I am immensely proud of my surrogacy career and having  babies who are loved by their families. “Surrogacy has brought me and the families I helped immeasurable joy, but also led to the darkest times of my le. “Surrogacy is the ultimate gt that one woman can do for another. “But there is a darker side when it goes wrong – the heartbreak, emotional roller- coaster and acrimony are devastating.”  Sadly that was the case with her ninth surrogate baby. She says: “This little boy was accidentally created with an act of love between my partner and I. We didn’t know it when we handed him over. “We agonised over what to do, but in the end decided to let them keep him. “People have asked, ‘How could you give this baby away as this one is yours ’, but many of the surrogate babies I have given away have been mine biologically. “The dference was he was also Paul’s. We have never stopped thinking about him. We live in hope he is aware of us and, when he turns , he’d like to see us.” In , Carole agreed to become a surrogate for the UK-based mother and self-inseminated with sperm from the businessman husband. Surrogates were advised not to have sex at all until they were pregnant, but Carole thought that was unrealistic. She says: “I never promised that I would never have sex, but my husband and I took precautions.” When she became pregnant the couple were overjoyed. They attended scans and the birth and Carole stayed with them for a week afterwards. But six weeks later the furious father phoned the surrogacy agency to tell them a DNA test showed the baby was not his. A second test confirmed it. Carole says: “It was just a terrible situation for everyone. I remember repeatedly saying to the surrogacy agency, ‘Do they want him ’ “As a surrogate you are having a baby for someone  – you don’t bond, you haven’t prepared for a child, in fact for nine months you are mentally distancing yourself from the baby. “But we also had to make a decision – what were we going to dothey did hand him back  And what were we going to do now we had the knowledge he was biologically ours ” Paul, now , is Carole’s second husband and they had no children together, although both had children from previous relationships. Carole, , from Colchester, Essex, who has two daughters of her own, says: “We had an honest and open discussion about whether we would keep him or put him up for adoption. “In the end, Paul made the decision. He said, ‘If they don’t want him, we will bring him up’. We decidedthey still loved him and wanted to keep him, we would let him stay with them. “The decision was immense, as this little boy was dferent because he was my partner’s too – and we hadn’t had a child together. While it was an agonising decision, I still think it was the right one for him and his parents. “I’d spent nine months believing this child was theirs and psychologically distancing myself from him.“I didn’t emotionally invest in the pregnancy, as it would break your heart every time you handed a child over.“He’d been with them for six weeks – and I’d already begun thinking of the next couple I was going to help. “They’d loved him from the moment of his conception and nurtured him – I’d just provided the womb. I was able to carry a baby without emotionally connecting with them. “It was only when I nurtured my two daughters after their birth that I bonded and loved them as a mother should.” After the boy was adopted by the couple, Carole says they kept in contact by post for a few years. But “relations were completely broken down” and the letters stopped. She says: “I am in contact with almost all of my surrogate babies – but not him. As the years pass we think about him all the time. Paul has developed a heart condition and it would break my hearthe never met him.” Carole admits she looked for her son on social media and found a picture of him, aged six or seven, on his mum’s Facebook profile.She says: “It is a natural curiosityyou have created a human being to know about them. “I’ve never seen his creation as a mistake. It was a blip… but a blip that created a wonderful human being. So I can honestly say I don’t regret it. But what I do deeply regret is not having any contact at all.” She is now looking to June when he turns . Carole says: “When babies are adopted you can register an interest and leave a letter so that once they turn  they can find out who you are andyou want contact. “So I’ve written a letter and hopefully,he knows about his background, he’ll want to get to know us. “I have thought more about this surrogate child than any of the others. I can honestly say I’d be heartbrokenhe didn’t want to know us.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesLovePregnancyWorld recordsAdoptionSurrogacyDaily Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mans last words before going
story: Mans last words before going under for a pig heart transplant shared by doctorTerminally ill David Bennett signed up for the experimental procedure because he wanted to live and getting a pig heart installed was his only choice, and now hes awake and smilingDavid Bennett has become the first person to have a full pig heart transplant Image: UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND SCHOOL OFByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A man who became the first in history to have an entire pig heart transplanted is awake and apossmilingapos after his surgery - and now a doctor has shared his last words before going under.Terminally ill David Bennett was told he had just months left to live as he had a heart disease but he was determined to survive so he signed up for the experimental procedure. He went under the kne at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore on Saturday, January , for a nine-hour procedure performed by Dr Bartley Grfith. The operation has so far proven to be a success, and Dr Grfith has revealed his patientaposs last words, which were: I want to live, andI donapost youaposll learn something. What do you think of the incredible procedure  Let us know in the comments...David, a -year-old labourer, was given the heart from a pig that had been gene-edited to make it more compatible, lowering the chances that his immune system would reject the organ. Appearing on ITV this afternoon, Dr Grfith said: He himself said, aposI want to live, andI donapost youaposll learn something. I wish we knew more but weaposre learning a lot every day with this gentleman and so far weaposre happy with our decision to move forward and he is as well, heaposs got a big smile on his face today For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. Experts say it is too soon to know whether Davidaposs body will accept the organ and the next few weeks are critical for his recovery.Sparking to ITV, his son, David Jr, said: He realises the magnitude of what was done and he really realises the importance of it.He could not live, or he could last a day, or he could last a couple of days. I mean, weaposre in the unknown at this point.  In the first three days since receiving the organ, David has shown no signs of rejection.Mr Bennett agreed to be the first to risk the experimental surgery in December, hoping it would give him a new le. Mr Bennett decided to undergo the pioneering surgery on the experimental treatment because he would have died without a new heart, had exhausted other treatments and was too sick to qualy for a human donor heart, family members and doctors said.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. title: mum sparks debate confessing shes
story: Mum sparks debate by confessing shes hiding her pregnancy from her new employerA pregnant woman has sparked an interesting conversation about whether women should be obliged to tell a new employer that theyre pregnant when accepting a job offerThe mum-to-be got a job offer two weeks after discovering shes pregnant Image: Getty ImagesByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan | comments A mum-to-be has sparked an interesting debate online, after confessing she has no plans to tell her new employer sheaposs pregnant any time soon.The woman, who only recently found out sheaposs expecting, was offered a new job just two weeks later with a new employer, but didnapost feel the need to reveal the pregnancy when accepting the offer.I recently found out I was pregnant. Only two weeks later, I got a job offer, which I accepted. I didn’t say anything about my pregnancy as it’s so early, she explained on Redditaposs AITA forum.I’ve also heard of employers discriminating against pregnant workers by not hiring them, and I wanted to avoid that.  Things were going well for the mum-to-be, until last week when she decided to tell a few family members about both the new job and the pregnancy. One of them asked meI told the boss about being pregnant. When I said no, he got disapproving and said I shouldn’t have lied about it, she continued. I didn’t say anything, but I don’t think I’m in the wrong. My goal is to protect myself and the baby’s wellbeing, and having a job with maternity leave and a guarantee of work when Iwill help me. The mum then turned to Reddit to question whether others agreed with her decision not to reveal her pregnancy to her new employer. You gotta look out for you. Youaposre under no legal obligation to disclose and they arenapost even allowed to ask either, one Reddit user commented. Another added: You didnapost lie about being pregnant. You simply didnapost volunteer it, and the employer didnapost violate the law by asking. You didnapost need to disclose, plusyou are before  weeks along, it is still REALLY early. However, another disagreed: I think youaposre in the wrong unless youaposre really stellar and donapost count on keeping that job. You gotta do whataposs best for you so itaposs justied but itaposs gonna suck for your coworkersthey have to pick up your slack especiallyyou were supposed to come in to ease up the workload. It also sucks for the employerthey are smaller as they would much rather have hired someone  but it shouldnapost really matterthey are a larger company. And this will probably have negative repercussions because whoever did the hiring may be more reluctant to hire younger women because this situation may remain with them.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum who blind 15 years
story: Mum who was blind for  years regains her sight after discovering misdiagnosisMum Connie Parke discovered she was blind for  years for no reason after doctors finally discovered that she had been wrongly diagnosed all those years agoConnie Parke, , is now able to watch her grandchildren play Image: UCHealth   SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsMum Connie Parke hadnapost seen her childrenaposs faces for more than a decade when a simple procedure changed her le. After being misdiagnosed, she found her le getting much smaller as her vision gradually declined. She had no idea how her adult daughter looked, and last saw her eldest grandchild when they were just three weeks old. Doctors told her that she was suffering from detached retinas or glaucoma. But the diagnosis was incorrect – she actually had cataracts, which could be removed easily and restore her sight. After having the surgery, the mum now has   vision in both eyes after being left blind for  YEARS. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Emotional Connie has spoken about how it felt when surgery finally restored her vision last year, after an ophthalmologist diagnosed cataracts, one of the most common adult vision issues. Connie, from Aurora, Colorado, USA, said: “People need to get rechecked because I was blind for  years probably for no reason. Theyaposve been doing cataract surgeries for years.” She added: “The day the retina specialist told me he saw no diseased retinas, my husband and I instantly got upset.  “I had a little resentiment towards the doctors that couldn’t find anything wrong or told me all these things were wrong, but the God’s honest truth is the day they took the patch off my eye, and I could see, it took all that anger away.” Connie first began noticing halos and prisms on car lights while driving in  and went to a doctor who told her she had glaucoma. “Three weeks later, I had lost even more sight and peripheral vision,” she said.  The mum was told that her loss of vision was sadly inoperable and she would become blind. “I didnapost believe it until I started hurting myself,” she said.“I was getting lost, falling down stairs, falling up stairs and setting myself and my house on fire. I had lost over % of my sight in five and a half months.”In a drastic move to reclaim her independence, she relocated from Montana to Denver, Colorado in , to attend blind school.  Determined not to let her blindness stop her, she continued doing outdoorsy things she had always loved, such as ice skating, kayaking, camping and attending sporting events and concerts. “I was so happy to be in the nosebleeds screaming my lungs out and not seeing anything,” she said. I just lived le as much as I possibly could the way I did before I lost my sight.” But there were some major things that were dficult to adjust to - and she lost some of her independence. “I wasnapost really sure to how to use a cane and I would keep walking into bushes,” she said.  “I had to have somebody with me when I cooked to make sure the food looked okay. I couldn’t vacuum and had to sweep in a pattern.” In , Connie was referred to the UCHealth Sue Anschutz-Rodgers Eye Center and the ophthalmologist told her she was suffering not from a detached retina, but very dense cataracts and suggested surgery. “On November th, the doctor did my right eye. When they took my patch off the next day the first thing I saw was the nurse’s eyebrow, eyelashes and pupil and I started crying,” Connie said. “She had me read an eye chart and the first line I read was  .  “I think the doctor was as surprised as me because he had made it perfectly clear he wasn’t promising me measurable vision. “I had the second eye done and right after Thanksgiving, I was seeing   out of both eyes. Now, Connie has retired her guide dog Talulah Mae to a regular dog and has a job as a unit clerk with UCHealth. She has been able to see her eldest grandchild for the first time since she was an infant, and her other eight grandkids for the first time ever.  “The eldest doesnapost look anything like she looked when she was three weeks old,” Connie joked. She also enjoys watching things that most people take for granted. “I got to watch all the flowers bud and the trees grow leaves,” she said. “People think itaposs tedious to watch grass grow, but when you havenapost seen a blade of grass in years, you watch the grass grow.” She added that it was painful to see herself ageing. “The hardest thing was looking in the mirror, because I never thought about myself aging,” she said. “I had no idea who that was looking back at me.” She was, however, happy to see her husband Robert again. “He’s still the most handsome man ever and Iaposm still completely in love with him,” she said. Now, she’s excited to retake the vacations the couple had been on when she was blind. “He took me to the Oregon coast, Yellowstone and all through the Rockies. Now I just want to go see it again,” she said. “Well, I want to go see it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON DisabilityViralVision Care" data-immediate"data-immediate" to FREE email alerts with news to brighten your daySubscribeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news weird-news teen-left-temporarily-blind-after-"Student shows her allergic reaction from eyelash extensionsByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan A student has revealed how a dodgy set of  eyelash extensions left her temporarily blind and her eyelids stuck together - with her real lashes still struggling to grow back a month later.Jasmine Dewhurst, who is currently studying business and marketing in Liverpool, went to get her lashes done for the second time last month, which resulted in a horric allergic reaction after the beautician failed to do a patch test.The -year-old says the experience was awful from start to finish, after the inexperienced technician accidentally glued some of her bottom lashes to the extensions as well, gluing her eyelids together before the allergic reaction even set in. I showed her a picture of how I wanted them and when she was done she said apostheyaposre a bit more full than you wantedapos so straight away that was a big red flag, Jasmine, who is originally from North Wales, recalled.  She showed me them in the mirror and I wanted to cry because I really didnapost like them. She had managed to glue the top lashes with some of my bottom lashes so one of my eyes was a bit glued together and I couldnapost open it properly. I was sat in the car after trying to detach my bottom lashes and I had to yank some fake lashes out which pulled some of my natural eyelashes out as well. After that they were okay for about a week but then they got really painful - my eyes felt really hot and itchy. They stung so much and kept watering. However, things went from bad to worse when the teen woke up the next morning and couldnapost open her eyes at all, sending her into a panic. I couldnapost see anything and I didnapost know what was wrong. I felt my eyes and they were glued together with that gooey stuff eyes get, she said. I got hot salty water to try and wash it off but it was so solid I had to start picking it off and it was pulling more eyelashes out.  Jasmine visited her doctor when she woke up the following day with her eyes crusted shut again and was prescribed creams, eye drops and tablets to tackle the allergic reaction. After removing the problematic eyelash extensions herself she has now been left with aposgappyapos natural eyelashes and continued inflammation of her eyes and eyelids. Jasmine said: When I got them done I never knew anything like that couldaposve happened. I just thought the worst that could happen is theyaposd get a bit itchy but they were so painful and swollen, it was awful. I had eyelash remover serum so I rubbed that along the lashline and used Vaseline as well and combed through my lashes. I didnapost manage to get them all off for about a month. The irritation hasnapost fully gone away, they still get swollen now. Immediately after the lashes were off and I was still having eye issues I had barely any lashes, my eyes were basically bald. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. The student had a smoother experience of getting her eyelashes done a year earlier with another beautician who applied a patch test behind her ear.She found the new lash technician on Instagram after a friendaposs recommendation and opted for full volume, Russian-style lashes that were on offer for £ at the time.Jasmine claims the new beautician never mentioned a patch test, leaving her thinking it wasnapost a necessity. But after her horror allergic reaction and being left with an almost aposbaldapos lash line, she is now urging all eyelash extension customers to request a patch test. Jasmine said: The lady who previously did my eyelashes did a patch test behind my ear but I didnapost really think much of it. When this girl didnapost do it I just thought maybe thataposs something the other girl just does but then I found out afterwards that theyaposre all supposed to. My eyelashes are just starting to grow back now so I can put mascara on again. If theyaposve healed enough one day, which I imagine could take years, then I would get them done again but definitely make sure to get a patch test. Everyone should make sure they get a patch test and know the ingredients of the gluethey can because clearly Iaposm allergic to whatever was in that glue.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: woman sacked after refusing buy
story: Woman sacked after refusing to buy a Christmas present for a co-workerA woman was fired from her job after she refused to buy a secret Santa gt for a coworker when she learned that he wasnt a Christian, even though he followed the rules and bought one for someone A woman was fired after refusing to buy a secret Santa gt for a co-worker Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A woman was fired from her job after she refused to buy a secret Santa gt for a co-worker - because he wasnapost a Christian.Sharing his story anonymously, a man said that when the gts were handed out just before Christmas he was left empty-handed, despite putting his name into the hat. Then he remembered a conversation heaposd had with a coworker, Jen, and how she was a little surprised when he said he no longer went to church. He then approached Jen and she admitted that she had got his name in the secret Santa ring, and had chosen not to buy him anything as he was aposprofiting offapos the religious holiday. Do you think Christmas is just for Christians  Let us know in the comments...Taking to Reddit, the man said: A few days before Christmas we all were supposed to exchange our gts. I gave the person I picked their gt and then I was waiting to receive mine, I didnapost know who picked me of course but eventually it seemed like everyone had gotten their gts except me. Then Jen came over and said she was the one who picked my name, but since I didnapost believe in Christmas there was no reason for her to get me a gt in celebration of it. I was honestly shocked but she left before I could say anything. It did bother me a bit but I decided to let it go because I didnapost want any drama.  A friend, named Amy, learned of what happened to the man and she encouraged him to report it, but he insisted he didnapost want any trouble so left it at that. But when he ed from his Christmas break he was called into his bossaposs office who wanted to know the whole story, and they then said they would be having a chat with Jen. He continued: Yesterday I noticed Jenaposs desk was cleared out, I asked Amy about it and she said Jen had been fired.  I feel bad because I didnapost care about getting a present that much and I donapost think itaposs something that warrants getting someone fired. After sharing his story online, the man was inundated with advice from strangers who said it was a good thing the boss got involved. One said: She didnapost get fired for not getting you a present, she got fired for the things she said and did. She did this to herself, not you. While a second added: Her behaviour got her fired, not you being honest when asked a question by your supervisor. And a third wrote: Your coworker got herself fired for trying to stick her personal beliefs where they donapost belong and showing blatant prejudice towards other people in the office. Telling the truth about what happened landed your work environment and coworkers in a less toxic place.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news woman-stitches-after-being-duped-"TikToker in hysterics after purchasing overly revealing dressByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsItaposs no secret that online shopping can be a little hit and miss. Sometimes items arrive looking exactly as described but others... itaposs a little disappointing.Sadly, one Amazon knows this all too well after ordering a cute little black dress from TikTok, only for it to arrive and barely protect her modesty. The TikTok user, who goes by the name Girlfriend online, bought a fullblack dress with a plunging neckline and extremely high slits up the front, which leave very little to the imagination. Posting from her handle @girlfriendxoxoxo, she explained: So I bought a new dress off Amazon. It looked really really cute online, but on me... I’m just dying. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. This is the dress. I’m laughing because I just can’t decide what to do. There’s not enough fabric here and there’s definitely not enough fabric here, continued, while laughing her head off. I’m giggling, sorry, because it’s funny to me - I have a very cute body but I’ve been duped by Amazon, dammit! Despite her giggles, many of her followers were quick to comment saying just how good she looks in the dress. That is absolutely gorgeous on you, one wrote, while another added: I love the way it looks! A third wrote: Itaposs such a cute dress though, is there any chance youaposd be able to tailor it ! Fortunately, the creative woman was able to find a work around to make the dress work, and ended up styling it with a gorgeous black corset on top and it looks amazing.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: girl 10 able smile first
story: Girl, , able to smile for first time in years after facial tumour finally removedHoussainatou, ten, began suffering with pain in her mouth when she was just a toddler and her family were shocked to see the lump grow over the years - eventually forcing her to quit schoolHoussainatou underwent several rounds of patient selection screenings before she was accepted for free surgery Image: Shawn Thompson   Mercy Ships SWNSByCharlotte Penketh-King:,  Jan | commentsA -year-old girl is finally able to smile for the first time in years after surgeons saved her le by removing a facial tumour. Houssainatou, , began suffering with pain in her mouth when she was just a toddler and her family were shocked to see the lump grow over the years. With the facial tumour eventually protruding from the little girlaposs face and forcing her to quit school at just eight years old, her father Souleymane feared his daughter would struggle and die young. Incredibly, doctors managed to save the young girlaposs le with surgery onboard a hospital ship.The facial tumour was removed and the ten-year-old girl is now living a normal le at home with her grateful family.Maize farmer Souleymane, who lives in a town in the highlands of Guinea with his we, daughter Houssainatou and her four siblings, said: I cannot believe it. She is so beautul! I am so happy and so excited to bring her home to see the family.  I can only get enough food to feed my family, but not extra. Iaposd never have the means to take care of surgery for my daughter. We kept praying, and worrying, and looking for help. My heart is free now. The fear is gone. I used to spend every day afraid she would die young, but now I will spend my time helping her have a future. The proud father added: I want her to become a doctor so she can help people the way she herself has been helped. The le-saving surgery came thanks to Mercy Ships - a charity which delivers free le-saving surgery in west and central Africa. Houssainatou underwent several rounds of patient selection screenings before she was accepted for free surgery onboard hospital ship, the aposAfrica Mercyapos. After just one day and a four hour surgery, Houssainatou was able to see herself in the mirror, tumour-free, for the first time in her young le and is now living le to the fullest. title: huge asteroid bigger big ben
story: Asteroid, artwork" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-.jpg" width"" "" NASA classies anything passing within  miles of Earth as a Near-Earth-ObjectImage: Getty Images Science Photo Library RFByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A massive asteroid wider than Big Ben is tall will pass Earth today - just days before a bigger one is set to fly by. The rock, dubbed Asteroid  YD by NASA, is set to come within .million miles of our planet today as it whizzes through space.The asteroid measures a massive -metres wide making it wider than famous Westminster landmark Big Ben is tall. Despite its impressive size, it is slightly too small to be considered a potentially hazardous object - a name given to space junk discovered by the space agency that could prove a threat.While confirmed for today, NASA did not give an exact time this asteroid would be visiting. Another asteroid - which is far larger than YD and roughly two and a half times the size of the Empire State Building - is set to swing by Earth on January  at .pm Eastern time . Asteroid PC - which is .km in diameter- will be hurtling through space .million miles away from Earth.It will be our closest encounter with this particular asteroid for at least the next  years, according to inverse.And itaposs so close that amateur astronomers may be able to catch a glimpse from their gardens, according to the publication.  Relating to todayaposs rock, the .million-mile gap may seem massive, but is actually rather modest in space terms. In fact NASA classies anything that passes within million miles of Earth as a Near-Earth Object . Due to the distances they fly in from, tiny changes in their trajectories could be of concern for Earth scientists. Scientists track thousands of these to observe how close they are coming to Earth. And  YD is not the only asteroid set to become a Near-Earth Object in the coming weeks. There are three more that are set to pass by the globe before it does so. The  YK, which measures m wide, will fly within ,miles of the planet this Sunday. And then  YE, which is a measly m wide, will pass by on January , getting within .million miles of Earth. The third and final asteroid is  AP, the smallest at only m across, and passing on January , at .million miles from us. title: italian prince branded stingy ex
story: Italian prince branded stingy by ex after though he showered her with lavish gtsPrince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa has launched legal action against Tanya Yashenko months after she filed a lawsuit against him - but the pair still spent Christmas and New Year togetherPrince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa with girlfriend Tanya Yashenko Image: InstagramByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan A legal row has broken out between an Italian prince and his girlfriend, who branded him stingy despite him showering her with lavish gts. Prince Giacomo Bonanno di Linguaglossa, , is believed to have met -year-old Tanya Yashenko, from Belarus, at a dinner party in . It is said the couple enjoyed a whirlwind romance, holidaying in destinations such as Monte Carlo, Dubai and the Males. The Times reported he also gave her a Mercedes worth €,, a €, share in a Rome bed and breakfast, expensive jewellery and €, to help her to rent a flat in the centre of Rome. According to Italian media, Yashenko filed a legal complaint against the prince last year, alleging that he was stalking her and hired a psychiatrist to assist with her case.However, newspaper Il Messaggero reports that the expert has now switched sides and accuses Yashenko of taking advantage of the psychological fragility of Linguaglossa.The Italian press also reportedly obtained text messages exchanged between the pair, where she criticised the prince for not being generous enough. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.According to the , Ms Yashenko said: “If you wanted to, you would transfer half your investments in Italy to me, but you’re stingy.The messages emerged after the prince launched his own legal battle against Yashenko last month, accusing her of “circonvenzione d’incapace”, an Italian legal term that means “exerting undue influence over persons who are non-compos mentis. It is claimed the prince was left traumatised after the break-up of his earlier marriage. Yashenko has denied any wrongdoing and has insisted that the prince withdraw his accusations. At the weekend, the Italian prince took to his Facebook page, where he said he wanted to “publicly apologise to my partner Tanya Yashenko for my  statements. He added: I would like to explain that jealousy is a big reason for my actions. But the gts I gave I don’t want back.” It also emerged that the pair spent Christmas and New Year together.But the princeaposs lawyer Armando Fergola told the: She continues to try to manipulate him. He has certainly not withdrawn his accusations and will not do so.“He is still very fragile and the love affair has clouded his judgment. The primary aim of this case is to protect him from her, both psychologically and economically. Getting her to pay back the money is a secondary objective.” Read MoreRead MoreFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Love" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pioneering-glasgow-doctor-margaret-kerr-saved-lives-hundreds-premature-babies
story: COMPASSIONATE and dedicated, Dr Margaret Kerr’s work in Glasgow saved the lives of hundreds of premature babies. The consultant paediatrician at what was then the Royal Hospital for Sick Children at Yorkhill was a leading light in neo-natal medicine. She once said in an interview with the Evening Times: “I love babies – we are no longer just saving le but producing healthy future citizens. That gives us all pride and pleasure.”

story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. title: scottish government extends hardship fund for pig farmers
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. title: aberdeenshire bins left overflowing due to covid staff shortages
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. title: council votes on aberdeenshire platinum jubilee day off
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. title: raf lossiemouth ninth poseidon arrives
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
